column4: I have badblocks on disk (200 or above) found by `badblocks <device>`. While googling I've found information that badblock -w (write-mode) will force harddrive to internally fix badblocks using special free area of disk left for that purpose. Has anybody done that?
isn't fsck meant to fix badblocks?
i'm using ext3
then why not use fsck?
that's the recommended way to go around fixing bad blocks/drives playing up
but e2fsck -c will mark damaged area, and I'm talking about disk-internal-fixing.
that should all be in fsck, reboot into the recovery area, or from a livecd and just fsck the entire drive, it should repair bad blocks as well
it's not root partiotion, no need of livecd
so you don't know the answer to my initial question, do you?
then just run sudo fsck /dev/whatever
does it check for badblock without -c option?
it should do
are you guessing?
well I did this procedure a couple of days ago and it worked :)
and from what I can interpret from man fsck it will fix bad blocks
have you badblocks on this device?
yes
just make sure you do fsck /dev/whatever instead of e2fsck /dev/whatever
the -c option is used when you don't want the bad blocks to be repaired, just recorded
thanks for your help (btw I have't know that e2fsck and fsck are different commands)
btw, what number of badsectors have you found?
I honestly can't remember. I know it was after a failed gparted edit and I just ran fsck /path/to/drive and it fixed it all up
thanks for your time
